div.p: LOVE in the EAST; OR, Adventures of Twelve Hours: A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS.
WRITTEN BY THE AUTHOR OF THE STRANGERS AT HOME.
AS PERFORMED AT THE Theatre-Royal, Drury-Lane.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR W. LOWNDES, NO. 77, FLEET-STREET. MDCCLXXXVIII. PRICE 1s. 6d.
THE Reader is requeſted to obſerve, that the Paſſages omitted in the Repreſentation at the Theatre are here preſerved, and diſtinguiſhed by inverted Commas, as from Line 18 to Line 27 in Page 4.

div.head: TO THOMAS LINLEY, ESQ.
div.p: IT may appear ſingular, that, becauſe I can flatter myſelf with being numbered among your friends, I ſhould, for that very reaſon, dedicate this Opera to you, without aſking your permiſſion: but it is my knowledge of your diffidence, that has prevented that ſolicitation.

As I ſhould, however, fear to forfeit my claim to your friendſhip, by giving you, in public, that praiſe which you ſhun
in private, I muſt content myſelf with the hope, that you will conſider this as an attempt to prove the eſteem and regard with which

closer.signed: I am, Dear Sir, Your moſt obedient, and faithful humble Servant, J. C.

div.p: IT is ſo uſual for the Author of a Dramatic Piece, on its Publication, to thank the Performers; that, on ſome Occaſions, a Writer might be led to withhold his Acknowledgments, left Truth ſhould be conſidered as mere cuſtomary Compliment.

The Author of the following Opera is not, however, ſubjected to that Riſque, when he acquits himſelf of a Duty, by giving the Performers a Tribute of Praiſe, the Juſtice of which is atteſted by the Voice of the Public.

body.head: LOVE IN THE EAST: A COMIC OPERA.

div.head: SCENE I. The Landing-place at Calcutta.
div.stage: [A number of people, Indians and Europeans, walking on the ſhore.—Several ſailors come to the front of the ſtage, as if juſt arrived, and ſing a chorus.]

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: HAIL to India's happy ſhore,
Where Nature from her choiceſt ſtore
Her bleſſings gives with bounteous hand,
And decks with ſmiles her favourite land.
Our dreams of danger now are o'er,
Hail to India's happy ſhore.

lg.head: DUETTO.
lg.l: No more the hidden rocks we fear,
No more the whiſtling winds we hear,
Which threaten devaſtation wide,
As Ocean rolls his troubled tide.

div.stage: Captain COROMANDEL comes forward with STANMORE.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Captain Coromandel,—once more welcome to Bengal.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Ah, my old friend Stanmore; I expected to have ſeen you in England before now.—Well, Sir, what news in Bengal?—How is your old friend and patron, Colonel Bentley; as whimſical as ever?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: As well beloved in the ſettlement as ever, I promiſe you: the Colonel's ſingularities do not cloud his virtues;—while others court eſteem, he commands it.—You know he has long fought under the banner of plain dealing.

sp.speaker: "CORO.
sp.p: Oh, that's a ſervice in which there is but bad pay.—He won't be able to enliſt many recruits."

sp.speaker: "STAN.
sp.p: But then the honour!"

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: "Why, as you ſay, if he loves the honour of fighting, he will have enough—for with plain dealing, he will be ſure to find enemies in plenty every where."—And how is the charming young lady, whom the Colonel has taken under his patronage?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Ormellina, you mean.—She is a charming creature indeed—but ſtill unmarried.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe ſhe won't remain ſo long;
the Colonel has, no doubt, taught her to be obedient, in order to train her up for a wife.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: A wife! No, no, ſir, the Colonel is too much a man of honour, to think of uniting threeſcore and eighteen.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: But what has honour to do in the buſineſs, my dear Stanmore?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Not much, indeed.—I think an unfortunate young woman has far leſs reaſon to complain of the poor fellow who takes her purſe on the highway, than of the old dotard who robs her of her happineſs, under the title of marriage; and yet the ſame laws which encourage her to hang the one, command her to honour and obey the other.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: You ſeem to ſpeak feelingly.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I have but too much cauſe;—the woman I loved was thus ſacrificed.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Pſhaw, man, don't droop becauſe you are ſeparated from your miſtreſs; ſhe will love you the better when you meet: without a ſtorm now and then, we ſhould not enjoy fair weather.

lg.l: Ah! when ſafe at home arrived at laſt,
Where oft the maid you love has heard the ſecret ſigh,
She fondly hears your tale of dangers paſt;
How ſweet to kiſs the tear from beauty's eye!
With this reward in view, what manly boſom fears
To brave the various war which ſkies and waters wage?
The winds, the thunder's roar, unmoved he hears,
While future calms of love his hopes engage.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Beauty, then, ſhall bend at Mirth's gay ſhrine,
Shall hail the feſtive hour, and mock her fond alarms:
Your bumper as ſhe fills, the nectar'd wine
Becomes the happy mirrour of her charms.
With this reward in view, &c.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Here comes a paſſenger of mine, a taylor, with whom I muſt bring you acquainted; I think the fellow will entertain you.
Mr. Stanmore, this is Tom Twiſt,—a very whimlical fellow, who, not being ſatisfied with ſitting croſs-legged in London, is reſolved to cut out work for himſelf in Bengal.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I am his moſt obedient.—And pray, Mr. Twiſt, what buſineſs do you mean to follow in Bengal?

sp.speaker: "TWIST.
sp.p: The ſame buſineſs which every one elſe follows in Bengal; getting money, oh, Captain."

sp.speaker: "STAN.
sp.p: But in what line?—For there are various ways of carrying on that buſineſs.

sp.speaker: "TWIST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and ſome of them d—d ſtrange ways, they tell us in England.

sp.speaker: "STAN.
sp.p: And pray, Mr. Twiſt, on what do you mean to depend, in becoming a favourite of fortune?"

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Accompliſhments, Sir.—I can dance a cotillion tolerably; ſing twenty ſongs, about Jockies and Jennies, for the ladies; and play Malbrouk on the fiddle.—In ſhort I can do every thing but write and read, and my genius never could ſtoop to that.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: But tell me, how did you acquire theſe elegant accompliſhments?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: You know, Sir, I always moved in a genteel circle.—My maſter worked for none but people of quality: not a tradeſman in Weſtminſter could boaſt of a greater number of book debts.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: That muſt have been a vaſt happineſs!

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Yes; old Staytape ruined himſelf by his great connections—He viſited ſome of the firſt people.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: What! a taylor viſit the firſt people?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Aye, Sir,—two or three times a day ſometimes; but he was ſeldom fortunate enough to meet with them at home; they weretoo much engaged in paying off the debts of the nation, to attend to their own.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Well, Twiſt, a truce with your wit for the preſent. I have promiſed my friend Muſhroom to ſend you to him.—He wiſhes to have ſome clothes made up in a hurry; and if your needle goes but as faſt as your tongue, I ſhall gain credit by recommending you.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Mr. Twiſt, I heartily wiſh you ſucceſs.—We are all three brother adventurers, and however different our ſituations, our object is the ſame.

lg.head: TRIO, and CHORUS.
lg.l: We be three, who, doom'd to roam,
Have dared the dang'rous ſeas;
That land becomes our deareſt home,
Which gives us wealth and eaſe.
No other climes will we explore,
Nor ſearch the world around:
Our choice is fix'd on India's ſhore;
Our home ſhall be this ground.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Once more, my dear little adventurer, welcome to Bengal. Captain Coromandel's letter introduces you to me with the higheſt encomiums; but he omits to tell me what has occaſioned you to quit England in this diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Ormellina, what being is that in the creation, for whom woman feels a thouſand various emotions, who is her bleſſing and her torment, her tyrant and her ſlave, the man ſhe loves?—In ſhort, I am come to Bengal in ſearch of a huſband, no uncommon errand, I believe.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: But your ſtory.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Is told in a few words. The prayers and intreaties of an indigent mother forced me to marry where I could not love. The object of my affections quitted the kingdom in deſpair, and took paſſage for Bengal.—My auld Robin Grey is lately dead. I diſguiſed myſelf thus, and embarked for India, in the hope of diſcovering my lover, and ſharing with him that fortune, which I have ſo dearly acquired.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Generous girl!—And ſo this lover is my friend—Enſign Stanmore. But tell me, what is this hiſtory of me, which you ſay you have heard?

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: That you are an orphan—educated by Colonel Bentley as his daughter.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: That your lover's name is Warnford—that you are jealous of him with a woman of intrigue—a Mrs. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: "ORM.
sp.p: Who could have told you this?

sp.speaker: "ELIZ.
sp.p: All that relates to you and Mr. Warnford, I learned from Mrs. Muſhroom herſelf: I called at her houſe juſt now, with a letter of introduction from Captain Coromandel.—You ſeem ſurpriſed at my knowledge; but I ſhould think very meanly of myſelf, indeed, were I to be in any place two hours, without learning the ſcandal of the whole neighbourhood."

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: But you have no reaſon to ſuppoſe that Warnford requites her attachment.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: That I am not ſure of.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Oh that I were aſcertained of the contrary.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Hear me, O god of love,
Who canſt deſpair control;
From jealouſy's keen ſmart,
Relieve my tortured ſoul.
Hear me, thou mighty pow'r;
Far from my troubled breaſt,
Doubts, fearful phantoms, chaſe,
And ſoothe my ſoul to reſt.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: You ſhall not long remain in ſuſpence—I am now going again to Mrs. Muſhroom, and will contrive to gain information; but I vow I had forgot to tell you my name.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Your name!

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: You muſt know that, in order to conceal myſelf from my lover the more effectually, I have aſſumed this diſguiſe, and am at preſent Alexander M'Proteus, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: And why diſguiſe yourſelf from my poor friend Stanmore?

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Only till I have perplexed him a little.—Coquetry with a lover, is like playing with your lap-dog, "or kitten." The fonder you are of the pretty animal, the more delight you feel in teazing it. Come, come, my dear friend, I ſhall make you a convert to my laughing philoſophy.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: I wiſh indeed you could.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Depend upon it, I ſhall. None can pay more ſincere homage to Cupid, than we laughing lovers. You ſighing folks make him an eaſtern deſpot, and fall proſtrate before him; with us, he is an European prince—we bow and ſimper at his levee: you degrade him to the mere tyrant of ſlaves; we exalt him to a glorious ſituation—the monarch of happy ſubjects.

div.head: SCENE, MUSHROOM's Houſe.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Mrs. Muſhroom!

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Do you dine at home to-day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Perhaps not.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: You are not reſolved then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: No—yes—no—I won't dine at home.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: I am very glad of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I ſhall leave you to expoſe yourſelf as much as you pleaſe to-day, and not take the trouble of interpreting your nonſenſe to your company, to perſuade them you are not a fool.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: They'll never believe me to be otherwiſe than a fool, whilſt they remember I married ſuch a precious wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and is it not that precious wife who has introduced you to moſt of the company you keep in Bengal?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, you have indeed introduced me to all the rake-helly young dogs in the three provinces; they ſtick ſo cloſe to you, that, whenever you go out, you move like the queen bee, with a whole ſwarm after you.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: You don't mean to inſinuate that I have wronged your bed, Mr. Muſhroom?

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: Not I, my love—I would not inſinuate that, till I have proof of it, and I'm afraid you'll take care to keep that out of my reach."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, very well; but indeed what had I elſe to expect, when I married an illiterate, ſordid wretch, and twenty years older than myſelf into the bargain?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p:
Aye, that's an unpardonable crime in me. I never knew a woman leave age out of the liſt of a man's faults. What an aſs was I to marry a broken milliner from Bond-ſtreet, who brought out a face as badly patched up as
her reputation, for a venture to Bengal; beſides which, ſhe hadn't ſtock in trade enough to fill one of her own band-boxes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: A very fit match, Mr. Muſhroom, for an ignorant run-away ſhop-boy, with a mind as deſtitute of ideas as his pockets were of money.—The whole ſettlement knows your origin.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, I always meant they ſhould know it. I glory in it, that there was a time when Martin Muſhroom, one of the richeſt men in Bengal, had not half-a-crown in his pocket, nor a whole coat to his back.—Zounds!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Don't fly in a paſſion now.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Not I, egad. That we hate each other moſt heartily, you very well know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: And the worſt part of the ſtory is, that we muſt not own it before company.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: No—that's a curſed confinement upon us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Well, it can't be help'd, Mr. Muſhroom; as we are tied together, we muſt make the beſt of a bad bargain. Huſh! here is ſomebody coming.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mr. M'Proteus.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Shew him up.—Draw your chair cloſer.
My dear M'Proteus.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Ah! bleſſing o' ye're hearts—ye're a pattern for a' married folk.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] Yes, and a pattern that is pretty much in vogue, I believe.—We have been talking over ſome old ſtories; hav'n't we, my dear Mr. Muſhroom?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, my life, we always talk them over when we are alone. [aſide] I ſhan't be able to keep my temper much longer.—Well, my dear, I muſt leave you for an hour or two: if Coromandel ſhould ſend the taylor, let them ſet him to work to alter my blue and gold; and if Colonel Baton ſhould call, pray entertain him till I return.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Oh, that is the French officer you expect from Pondicherri.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: The ſame, my dear. He never was in Calcutta before. He is a man of gallantry, Mr. M'Proteus—a dangerous man among the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Then I'm reſolved to make a conqueſt of him. [aſide]—How do I look today, my dear?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Much better than you did— [aſide] before you were painted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Mr. M'Proteus: the only looking glaſs an old married woman has to conſult, is her huſband.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: You are reight, Madam:—like a looking glaſs, he'll let ye ſee aw ye're fauts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH,
sp.p: Well, if you muſt go, good bye, love. [leaning on Muſhroom's ſhoulder.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [kiſſing his hand] Adieu, my angel. You ſee, Sir, what it is to have a wife ſo d—d fond of one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
At length we are alone. "Oh, Mr. M'Proteus, what an acquiſition it is to
have a friend like you.—The moment I ſaw you, I diſcovered that we had kindred minds.

sp.speaker: "ELIZ.
sp.p: I houp, Madam, they wunna gree th' war for being relations."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: You will recollect I mentioned to you my fears, that Mr. Warnford might miſunderſtand my behaviour to him?

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: I remember it perfectly, Madam; I never forget my friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Indeed! Well, that is very diſintereſted to remember your friends while you forget yourſelf, and that you certainly do at this moment.—What is become of that charming Caledonian accent which graced your converſation? Ye're reight, Madam: like a looking glaſs, he'll let ye ſee aw ye're fauts. [mimicking] Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: I cry for quarter, my dear Madam; a ſlip of the tongue has betrayed me, to be ſure. The truth is, love induced me to aſſume this diſguiſe, which I muſt wear for two or three days. You ſhall then know who, and what I am. Come, madam, you need not fear to make me your confidant; I am too much in your power for you to apprehend I ſhould deceive you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide.] There is ſome reaſon in that.—Well, M'Proteus, I will convince you that I can be generous.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Then, Madam, to the ſubject of our converſation—Mr. Warnford.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Well, as I told you—I have chatted, laughed, rallied him, and have given into a thouſand little levities in which we innocent women indulge, without meaning any thing.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Certainly—Why, what can you do? If a ſmart fellow will attack you with a curſe me, madam, but you are a monſtrous fine woman, you would not be ſo ill bred as to bluſh, look fooliſh, and threaten to tell your huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: That would be ill breeding, indeed.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: To be ſure. Lud, why a declaration of love excites a woman to coquetry, as naturally as the ſound of a fiddle excites her to dance. Never mind, my dear Madam; ſcandal is a tax on pleaſure; and if the commodity cannot be ſmuggled, a woman of ſpirit will rather pay the duty than go without it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: But is it not very hard that ſcandal ſhould attack us women of ſpirit, who, inſtead of ſhrinking from Temptation, boldly meet him, put him to the rout, and ſhew the reſt of our ſex the way to victory and glory? My maxim, Mr. M'Proteus, is, that virtue ſhould be tried.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Therefore, I preſume, Madam, you have tried yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, I thank my ſtars, often, and often—do you know—

sp.speaker: "ELIZ.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, what a treaſure do you poſſeſs in ſuch a veteran virtue!—You muſt have great confidence in it."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: "Prodigious—I'll give you a proof of it."—I mean to give Warnford a private meeting, and in my own room too. Ha! ha! you ſeem ſurpriſed; but you don't conſider that ſo bold a propoſal will argue ſuch a confidence in my own prudence, that it muſt entirely deſtroy all his hopes of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: "ELIZ.
sp.p: No, really, I did not think of that.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: You have it in your power to witneſs the purity of my motives, in caſe my conduct ſhould be miſconſtrued; but" I have written a letter to Warnford, which I will ſhow you. [giving Eliza a letter.]

div.stage: Enter LUCY, who whiſpers Mrs. MUSHROOM, and exit.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: This will be bad intelligence for my poor friend Ormellina. But to the letter. [Reading] 'I am extremely anxious to remove any prejudice you may have formed to my diſadvantage. As I think that can be beſt done by a private interview, let me ſee you as ſoon as poſſible.—Three raps at my chamber-door will be your paſſport to the explanation propoſed by MARIA MUSHROOM.'

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: One of Warnford's ſervants happens fortunately to be in the houſe—It will be much better to ſend it by him, than by one of my own people. [takes the letter, and ſeals it.]
How d'ye do, Roſario? You muſt deliver a letter from this gentleman to your maſter.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Yes, Miſſee. [aſide] Dere always be ſome cus miſchief ven Miſſee be ſo civil.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: [aſide to Mrs. Muſh.] You have not directed the letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide to Eliz.] It would not be prudent for my hand-writing to appear on the direction—beſides, Roſario ſuppoſes the letter yours.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Shall I addreſs it then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
Oh, no; that will appear ſo
ſtrange to Warnford:—there is no neceſſity for any direction.—There, Roſario—there is the letter. [turning to Eliz.] I hope this will ſet my character in a proper point of view. It is really very troubleſome for people to fall in love with one in this manner—is it not, M'Proteus?

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know, Madam; love is like money, every one abuſes it, and yet I know not what we ſhould do without it.

sp.speaker: ROSARIO ſo •… s
sp.p: Ah! my mind miſgive m • .—Dis letter be no honeſt, no ſay any ting o • outſide—all white and clean outſide—nice and fair, like Miſſee—afraid though it be wicked and black within.—Poor Maſſa, why ſhould Roſario give him bad letter?—He be good maſſa—give me money for my poor father—never ſay to me rogue—raſcal—but always ſpeakee kind, and call my own name.

lg.l: Oh, I love my m • ſſa kind,
He be poor Indian's friend alone;
Ven he ſmile, den joy I find;
Ven he grieve, I ſure muſt moan.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: So de ſun, you may perceive him,
Make de rice •… lk grow ſo high:
Who, if him ben •… actor leave him,
Mourn him loſs, and droop, and die.

sp.p: But den maſſa be angry if me no give letter, me tink.—

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Eh bien! ma fille charmante—As monſieur be not at home, I vill pay my reſpect to madame.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Your name, Sir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Le Colonel Baton—French officier—come from Pondicherri.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: I will ſee if my miſtreſs is at home.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: You maitreſſe! Par ma foi, madame, I did ſuppo •… you vas de lati of de houſe—you be ſo jolie •… your figure ſo gentille, ſo negligee.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Ah, Sir!—you French gentlemen are ſo gallant.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Gallantrie! Ah, c'eſt mon metier—It be my trade—Cupid be mon general—I have been his ſoldier great many year.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir!—Dear, I ſhould think it is almoſt time for you to retire upon half pay. [going, Colonel ſtops her.]

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Ah! ma •… ere, have pity on my ſigh.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Sighs! O Lord, Sir, ſighing lovers are a ſet of the ſillieſt mortals.—I'll tell you how they torment themſelves.

lg.head: "AIR.
lg.l: "Fond Damon wiſhes • e were dead,
"Or when a heart gay Strephon play'd,
"Revoked, and trumpt it with a ſpade:
"While ſhe diſtracted tea •… her fan,
"And has hyſterics for a week,
"Becauſe the falſe, the f •… thleſs man,
"Let Celia's lap-dog tou •… his cheek.
"When they meet, Chloe paces the drawingroom o'er;
"He frowns at the ceiling, and then at the floor;
"She ſings, and he mutters •… ill eager to quarrel,
"Each certain of conqueſt, they ſtrive for the laurel.
"Zounds, Ma'am, you're •… conſtant—Sir, you are ungrateful.
"Yet hear me—No more Sir,—to me you are hateful.
"Rage, fury, diſtraction, deſtruction and death;
"Ha! ha! ha!—Oh! I'm quite out of breath.
"Take advice from dull folks, who make love in plain proſe,
"'Twill ſave you much trouble to follow our plan:
"Let no ſquabbles heroic diſturb your repoſe,
"But e'en kiſs and friends, as ſoon as you can."

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Ah! ha! ha! Litel divil—Je l'ai priſe! I'ave caught her. Ven ever doſe litel girls fall in loaf vid me, dey alvays laugh diablement—mais allons—now for de maitreſſe.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: [aſide] No—won't give letter to maſſa—Egod, have great mind to give it to Frenchman—don't like Fr •… chmans—bad letter good enough for him—a •… that will make joke.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p:
Une lettre! pour moi!—Ah ha! vidout directione! Somebody elſe in loaf avec moi; nous verrons. [opens, and reads it.] Private
interview—tr •… rap at my chamber door. Marie Muſhroom. Serviteur, Madame Muſhroom—Poor ladi—ſhe is ſtruck auſſi—ſaw me from the window, peut-etre.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſorry to tell you, my miſtreſs is out.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Ma ch •… e, I am ſorry to contradict you—but you are out yourſelf. Montrez moi la chambre de m • dame—de lady's chambre door—tree rap, ma •… lle eh!—

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Dear, Sir, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: I can't •… ll you dat, my dear,—only ſhew me madam • s room—voici la lettre.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [aſide] My miſtreſs's hand-writing, as I live! What is this to produce?

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: [giving her money] I am au deſeſpair, dat I 'ave no time to be more in love vid you à preſent, Mademoiſelle, but I ſhall 'ave dat honneur anoder time

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Oh dear, Sir, I am in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Allons! ma belle, allons!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Bleſs me, here is ſomebody coming; ſtep into that room, Sir, on the right-hand—I'll attend you preſently.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Come, come, Roſario, tell me truth—you are certainly in love with ſome pretty little Indian girl in this houſe—I meet you here continually—what ſay you, Lucy?

sp.speaker: ROSAR.
sp.p: [aſide.] If ma •… ſhould find out dat I no give him letter, wh •… ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Warnford, you are always talking about love.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p:
Well, Lucy; I own that my heart
yields like war to the impreſſion of the little god.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: I fancy the wax is ſoon hot and ſoon cold, and yields to a different impreſſion every day.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, Lucy:—it does not follow that I ſhould be inconſtant, becauſe I am attentive to the whole ſex.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: So deep within my heart
My fair one's image lies,
That only death's keen dart
Can reach my deareſt prize.
The oak firm rooted mocks the blaſt,
And dares its proud tyrannic ſway;
Yet when the angry ſtorm is paſt,
His leaves the zephyr's breath obey.
Firm fixt that love remains,
Increaſing ev'ry hour,
Which falſehood's ſway diſdains,
Yet bends to faſhion's power.

sp.speaker: "LUCY.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Warnford, my miſtreſs is not at home; and as for my maſter, I ſuppoſe you hardly come to inquire after him.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: No, i'faith, I came to inquire after an old friend of my father's, Colonel Baton, who, I hear, is arrived in Calcutta.—I expected to find him here.

sp.speaker: "LUCY.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you'll be diſappointed in your expectations.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: Perhaps he is not arrived."

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: And as for my miſtreſs, ſhe is not at home.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: No! why then I have half a mind to make love to you. Come, come, my dear Lucy, don't frown, but confeſs honeſtly with me that making love is no very unpleaſant amuſement.—Your eyes anſwer yes.—And what ſay you, my poor Roſario?—Nothing! Ah, I thought mine was an univerſal opinion.

lg.l: Tho' by fate it be decreed
Sorrow ſhall guard the lover's meed;
Yet Stoic apathy I ſcorn,
Yet ev'ry danger will I ſcorn.
He who would pluck the roſe, muſt dare the thorn.
Tho' love make me ſigh and grieve,
Still I would not be relieve;
I no fear his frown to meet,
He only frown to ſmile more ſweet.
Tho' by Fate, &c.

div.head: SCENE, Mrs. MUSHROOM's Chamber.
div.p: HEY day! do my ears deceive me, or did I hear Warnford's ſignal?—Three raps at my door!—How can he poſſibly have received my letter ſo ſoon? [raps] Hark!—The ſignal repeated! This is a lover's haſte, indeed! [ſhe goes to the door, and opens it, turning away her head, and affecting agitation. Col. Baton takes her hand, and follows her on.] My confuſion will ſcarcely ſuffer me to explain what I dare ſay muſt ſurpriſe you.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Oh no, Madame; I am uſed to deſe affaires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [turning round, and ſeeing him] Oh, heavens!—who are you, Sir, and what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Your commande, Madame—La voila. [ſhewing her letter] Permittez moi, Madame—Suffer me on my knee—

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Ruin'd and undone, Madam!—Here is my maſter return'd home ſuddenly, and is coming into your room.—If he ſhould catch the Colonel with you—

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p:
Don't be alarm, Madame; ve people of gallantrie never mind ſuch accidens.
[taking ſnuff] Put me in a cloſet, or under your bed, or vere ever you pleaſe, Matame.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: No, that will never do—We have but one chance for your eſcape—In that cloſet is a window, which looks into the garden—you muſt e'en jump out—it is not above ſeven or eight feet from the ground.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Seven or eight feet from de ground!—Pardonnez moi, Madame, it be impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Madame, I ſhould be vera happy to jump any vere for you; but I 'ave von litel malheur vill make it impoſſibel. I am trouble, Madame, vit de rheumatiſm in my knee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Unfortunate beyond every thing.—What a time for a man to have the rheumatiſm!

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Courage, Madam:—I have thought of an expedient to ſave both your reputation and the Colonel's lame knee. Twiſt, the taylor, is juſt arrived, and is now waiting at the gardendoor, for this very coat which I have in my hand—But we have not a moment to loſe—This way, Sir. [Lucy and Colonel go into a cloſet.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: By what ſtrange accident could this old Frenchman have got my letter?—Colonel Baton I think ſhe call'd him—the very man whom we expected here.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [without] Mrs. Muſhroom!—my dear!—Why, I ſay, Mrs. Muſhroom! [Lucy running haſtily from the cloſet.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: What ſhall I do, Lucy?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p:
We are all ſafe, Madam. As I told you, Mr. Twiſt happen'd to be waiting for me, at the garden-door—I call'd to him from the
cloſet; and the Colonel has bribed my gentleman to exchange clothes with him from the window, and will attend you as ſoon as he is dreſs'd—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: But how muſt I manage, Lucy?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam!—You muſt keep the old Colonel in good humour, by nods, winks, and tender glances—and leave the reſt to me.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [without] Mrs. Muſhroom!—my love—

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [opening the door] Dear, Sir, is it you?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [enters] Yes, it is me, Madam; and an unwelcome viſitor I am, no doubt. I ſuppoſe you had a gallant with you, my love.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I ſha'n't anſwer ſuch queſtions, Sir.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: Perhaps, then, Madam, you will anſwer me." [to Lucy] Is the gentleman diſpoſed of?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir; I am much obliged to you—I took care to provide for that, while you were knocking at the door.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: You did—hum—and pray, my good Jezebel, how did you contrive to get rid of him?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I wanted him to jump out of the window; but unluckily he had the rheumatiſm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Lucy, how can you talk ſo?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Let her alone—She tells lies with ſo good a grace, 'tis a pleaſure to hear her.—Well, my dear, go on.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: So, Sir, we were even obliged to hide the gentleman in that cloſet—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Why, you audacious ſlut, how dare you laugh at me in this manner?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, if you doubt my veracity—believe your own eyes. [goes to the cloſet, and brings out Col. Baton, dreſt in Twiſt's clothes, and an old coat of Muſhroom's hanging on his arm.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Hey day! why, who, in the name of nonſenſe, have we here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Who ſhould it be, but the taylor ſent to you by Capt. Coromandel, to alter your clothes?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: A taylor! he looks much more like a mountebank doctor.—Well, my old boy, is it not rather too late in the day for you to come to India?

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Diable! [as if clapping his hand to his ſword, recollects he has no ſword on.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Eh! what! Diable! [Lucy converſes with Muſhroom in dumb ſhew.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide to the Colonel] My dear Colonel, be patient—conſider, it is for my ſake.—

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: [aſide to Mrs. Muſhroom] Ah! Madame, pardonnez—I had forgot dat—To ſuffer diſgrace in de cauſe of beauty, is de triomphe, "de victory and glory."

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [to Lucy] A Frenchman, eh! Egad though he is a fierce-looking fellow.—Look ye, Mounſeer, I can't jabber your lingo, ſo I believe my wife muſt talk to you; ſhe can parlee voo a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Aye, aye; I'll releaſe him from your vulgarity, Mr. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Not till I have given him directions how my coat is to be alter'd, Mrs. Muſhroom.—Come here, Mounſeer, and let me try it on; though, on ſecond thoughts, I won't trouble you. Egad though I have forgot, all this time, to inquire after Colonel Baton. I am very anxious for his arrival.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I dare ſay you will find him a very agreeable gueſt.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: I dare ſay I ſhall; for I hear he is a great fool, with plenty of money—part of which will go through my hands, he! he! he! Indico tells me, in his letter, the ſilly puppy fancies every woman, who ſees him, is in love with him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—Indico means to laugh at you.—I underſtand the Colonel is a man likely to win any woman's affections.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Of moſt engaging manners.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: An agreeable perſon.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Not above the middle age, and with an excellent conſtitution, [aſide to Baton] excepting an old rheumatic complaint.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: A man of wit, politeneſs, and gallantry.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [to Baton] Why, what the devil makes you bow and grin ſo, Mounſeer? They are not talking of you.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: He feels the compliment to his countryman, Sir, as if it were to himſelf.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [rings a bell—enter Servant] Has Colonel Baton been here yet?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Colonel Baton, Sir!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Aye—the French gentleman I expected.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p:
French!—Dear, Sir, there is an outlandiſh-looking
gentleman now walking in the garden, with a white cockade in his hat.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: A white cockade!—Zounds, 'tis the Colonel!—I'll run immediately—no I won't—Give my compliments—and ſay, I ſhall be glad to ſee him here. [Exit Servant] Mrs. Muſhroom, he'll take it as a compliment, to be received in your dreſſing-room—I'm told that is quite the thing in France.

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: [aſide] Diable! dis be vilain avanture.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: What ſhall we do, Lucy?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [to Mrs. Muſh.] I'll give Mr. Twiſt his cue, never fear me. [aſide.]

div.stage: Enter TWIST, in Col. BATON's clothes.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [to Twiſt] My dear Colonel Baton, I am heartily glad to ſee you in Calcutta. [ſhaking hands with Twiſt] But, odſo, I forgot—perhaps he can't ſpeak Engliſh.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Let me talk to him, Sir; I'll warrant I'll contrive to make him underſtand us. [taking Twiſt aſide.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: This is a mighty queer kind of a Frenchman—he is as ſilent, and as ſhamefaced, as if he had been bred up in England.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [aſide to Twiſt] Bred up in England!—No bad hint that—purſue it by all means.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Oh, Colonel Baton! how ſhall I make you amends for all this?

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Madame, I vill have de honeur to tell you anoder time. [aſide] Bleſs me! what could make her ſo moſh in love vid me?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [to Lucy, aſide] And ſo I'm to paſs for the French Colonel—But are you ſure I ſha'n't get my bones broke for this?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [aſide to Twiſt] Pſhaw! you can't oblige the Colonel more—Come, begin.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [aſide to Lucy] And may I give myſelf as many airs as I like?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [to Twiſt] The more the better—be as impudent as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [aſide to Lucy] A match—I warrant you ſhall have no reaſon to complain of my modeſty. [goes up to Muſhroom, and claps him on the ſhoulder] Muſhroom, my dear old boy, how are you?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Thank ye, thank ye—but you need not have been ſo violent in your ſalutation.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: I have an Engliſh tongue, you find.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, and an Engliſh arm too—and you have learnt our country faſhion of aſking people how they do.—My dear Mrs. Muſhroom, this is Colonel—

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Pſha! zounds! the lady knows very well who I am—By your leave, Madam— [catches Mrs. Muſhroom in his arms, and kiſſes her] No offence, I hope.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: [aſide to Mrs. Muſh.] Ah, peſte! Madame. I am enragé—Shall I cut his troat?—Diable! I have no ſword.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: By no means, Colonel—The poor fellow means no harm.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: But, pray, Colonel, how does it happen that you ſpeak Engliſh ſo well?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Oh, I was bred up in England from a child—I was at ſchool in London.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Egad, I ſhould not ſuppoſe you had been at ſchool any where by your breeding. [aſide]—I'll take a pinch of your ſnuff, Colonel.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p:
I don't know whether I have a ſnuffbox
about me.—Oh, yes—here it is. [offering him ſnuff.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: What a handſome box! charming indeed.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis pretty enough—I think I never obſerved it before.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Pretty!—it is exquiſite.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: The box is much at your ſervice, if you like it.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, ten thouſand thanks. [aſide] This fellow will prove a fine pigeon.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: [aſide] Ah, ma chere tabatiere! my deare box! [aſide to Twiſt] Rogue! vilain!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Hey day! what does that taylor want with you?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know—perhaps he imagines my coat wants altering.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Why, I don't think it would be amiſs to—

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: It does look as if it was not made for me—that is the truth of the matter.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: He ſhall alter it for you.—Here, Mounſeer—take meaſure of this gentleman directly—He is your countryman; and if you don't alter his clothes to his liking—I'll have your ears cut off. [aſide] I may venture to bluſter a little, as the Colonel is preſent.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Oh, hang him—he is as aukward as if he had never meaſured a man for a ſuit in his life—I dare ſay I could alter the coat better myſelf—ſet him about your own clothes.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p:
Egad, there is no time to loſe, indeed; ſo go to work directly, Mounſeer.—I commit him to your care, Lucy—Lock him up, and give
him nothing to eat, or drink, till he has completed the job.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: [aſide to Col.] So it is your deſtiny to be my priſoner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: [to Lucy] Ah, ma chere—I did read dat deſtiny in your eyes ven I firſt ſaw you. [aſide] Pauvre fille! quite jealouſe of me—I muſt be kind to her. [Caſts a languiſhing look at Mrs. Muſhroom, and exit with Lucy.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: One muſt treat theſe fellows a little harſhly, to make them do their duty.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Certainly, certainly. Theſe taylors are a ſet of the moſt lazy, impudent—I'm glad the fellow is gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: So am I, moſt ſincerely.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: I am not ſorry for it. I did not much like his looks.—But, where are your letters, Colonel?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Letters!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Ay, from my friend at Pondicherri—and the bill which he adviſes having drawn upon one, in your favour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: This will diſcover all.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Bill!—Really, my memory is ſo bad. [ſearching his pockets.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Perhaps you have put them in your pocket-book.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: They may be there, for aught I know. [takes out a pocket-book.] Here, Muſhroom, look over the book for me. "I can't ſubmit to the trouble of doing it."

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] I don't know what to make of this Frenchman.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [taking a letter from his waiſtcoat-pocket] Here is another letter—perhaps this is for you. [giving it.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] Eh! a letter from my wife, and to this French puppy—An appointment—Three raps at my chamber-door—This is a fortunate blunder of his.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: 'Tis very remarkable, that, though I ſpeak Engliſh ſo well, I never could read it.—But pray, Muſhroom, at what hour do you dine? I really think eating and drinking a mighty agreeable relief to converſation.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] Egad, I ſhould think any thing a relief from your converſation.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: You'll excuſe my freedom—But I am always perfectly at eaſe, wherever I go—You know that's very polite.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: But, pray, my dear friend, is whiſpering a part of modern politeneſs?—You ſeem to deal in that mightily.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Whiſpering!—Why, my dear Sir, it is the perfection of eloquence.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: May be ſo—but I will take care you ſha'n't profit much by the uſe of it.

lg.l: Of all the various modes of ſpeech,
Which poliſh'd art, or nature teach,
With all the aids of bows, nods, ſimpers,
Grave looks, or ſentimental whimpers,
The whiſper plays its part the beſt,
With hints, which let you gueſs the reſt.
Tol de rol—you gueſs the reſt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Would you aſſume the lover's part,
A fig for ſighs, and tragic ſtart;
With ſly, inſinuating leer,
Approach, and whiſper in her ear;
Lord bleſs me, Sir!—I vow—proteſt—
Well, really—you—you gueſs the reſt.
Tol de rol—you gueſs the reſt.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Whate'er the faults of this poor ſong,
Or keen, or dull—or ſhort, or long;
Whate'er its faults, my friend, excuſe it,
Or whiſper, if you muſt abuſe it;
Applaud me, though it be in jeſt;
And whiſper—I ſhall gueſs the reſt.
Tol de rol—I gueſs the reſt.

div.head: SCENE, The Garden-Room belonging to Col. BENTLEY's Houſe.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: It does not ſignify talking, Stanmore; I will not diſcover to Ormellina, that ſhe is my daughter. I love the ſlut ſo well, that I muſt not let her know it.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: And ſo, Sir, you will ſtill continue the impoſition, of letting her ſuppoſe ſhe is an orphan, ſupported and educated by your bounty.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Certainly. It is that happy ignorance of her birth, which has ſaved her from the ill effects of my fondneſs; for, I am ſure, if I had once owned her for my daughter, I ſhould certainly have ſpoilt her. You know, Stanmore, I am one of thoſe fools, who are vulgarly called good-natured people, and who find themſelves involved in a thouſand difficulties, merely becauſe they can't ſay no to any thing.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Yes, I know that is your infirmity.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Whenever a man wanted to borrow a few guineas, which he never meant to repay, Jack Bentley was the man applied to; and I had the excluſive privilege of being pigeon'd by my friends, merely becauſe I was the beſt creature in the world. However, I ſoon found it was a damn'd misfortune to be ſo agreeable; ſo I e'en parted with my character, to ſave my money, and affronted my acquaintance, to prevent my being obliged to quit ſociety.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Ay, there it is, now—What a pity, that good-nature, like the dreſs of an officer in battle, ſhould be only a dangerous mark of diſtinction, for the enemy to aim at.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: How often have I envied poor Sam Sulky! He was a happy fellow—bleſt with the worſt temper I ever knew, and had the fineſt forbidding frown—never lent a man a ſhilling in his life—nobody praiſed him, and he praiſed nobody—ſo he grew rich, becauſe people did not like his company well enough to ruin him.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Ah, Colonel! you would not have changed places with him, for all that—Your natural diſpoſition—

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Stanmore, don't betray me, by calling me a good-natured man—Do act the part of a friend—and abuſe me behind my back.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Warnford.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: For his anſwer, I ſuppoſe.—He aſk'd my conſent, yeſterday, to marry Ormellina.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Well, Sir; and—

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: And I mean to try the force of his attachment, by leaving him a little while in ſuſpence—But he is here.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, I rejoice to ſee you.—Mr. Stanmore, yours.—I read your conſent to my marrying Ormellina, in your countenance.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: He who believes all he reads, young man, muſt be often wofully miſtaken.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: I cannot be miſtaken here, Sir—I depend on my author—Nature has traced benevolence and good-humour in every feature; and her characters have not been defaced by malice or hypocriſy.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Sir, you do me a great deal of honour, to fancy my face a gazette extraordinary of good news to you. But, I ſay again, that you are miſtaken; I am not benevolent—I am ill-temper'd, Sir, and moroſe; and, as for all the ſilly cant of lovers, I conſider it as the half-form'd dialect of children, an abuſe of language, which they correct as they grow older.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: It is the language of my heart, Sir; and while that heart beats, ſuch muſt be its effuſions.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: And ſo I am to infer, from all this, that, if I refuſe my conſent, you will run away with the girl.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Why look ye, Colonel—I will not anſwer for myſelf—if Ormellina will agree to it.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: [aſide] A fine fellow, i'faith!— [to him] This is beyond bearing, Warnford.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Nay, I predict that you will forgive me. You have a friend, who will infallibly make my peace with you—a conſtant friend, to whom you now owe ſome of your happieſt moments.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Eh!—what friend do you mean?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: The remembrance of what you were at my age—I'll be hang'd if you would not have done the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: No, no—indeed no, Warnford—though, to be ſure, at your age, I did not want for fire.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: You were in love, Sir?

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: In love!—Who could have ſeen my dear Sophia, without loving her? Oh, Warnford! ſuch a pair of eyes! ſuch a winning ſmile!—But I am a vile hand at deſcription—I ſhall never forget when ſhe got into the chaiſe to elope with me.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: You eloped with her then, Sir?

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Aye, my boy.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Her guardian had refuſed his conſent?

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Pſhaw! What ſignifies that?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Bravo, Colonel Bentley;—and o, glowing with youth, love, and high ſpirits, you aſſerted the privilege of a lover, and ſnatch'd a fine girl from the tyranny of caprice, as I would do now.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Eh!—Snatch a fine girl!—Caprice! Why, what the devil, I muſt explain myſelf, Warnford.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: The voice of Nature needs no explanation, Sir.

lg.l: The guardian, dear Sir, or, if you would rather,
Suppoſe, if you pleaſe, 'tis the young lady's father,
Capricious,
Avaricious,
Shuns the fond lover's ſuit,
And with frowns ſtrikes him mute.
Pray give me leave, Sir, my tale to purſue:
Well, what's to be done?
The lady's in tears,
The lover diſtracted;
Such mad pranks are acted,
Till love interferes,
And cries, off you muſt run:
Dear Sir, remember, 'twas once ſo with you.
As ſubjects, you know, to Cupid's dominion,
All lovers muſt bow to their ſov'reign's opinion:
From laws ſo delightful, ſay, who can depart?
The laws of a monarch, whoſe throne is the heart.
Huſh! huſh! remember, 'twas once ſo with you.
The picture is yours, Sir, the likeneſs is juſt,
And, tho' painted too young, that you'll pardon, I truſt;
Like you, I the dictates of Nature purſue:
Huſh! huſh! remember, 'twas once ſo with you.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Zounds! Stanmore, why didn't you ſtop me, when you ſaw me expoſing myſelf ſo? The dog took me unawares, and unfortunately ſurpriſed me into a fit of good-humour. He is a fine high-mettled fellow, faith.

sp.speaker: STANM.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, you may find him too much ſo.—You know he has given you fair warning of his intention to run away with Ormellina; and I think your only chance for preventing him, is, to own her publicly as your daughter immediately.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Surely I heard your name mentioned—Stop, I beſeech you; perhaps the converſation may be intereſting to you.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Egad, Stanmore, you are in the right—I will declare myſelf to Ormellina—ſhe ſhall know all the affection I feel for her. Tomorrow I will call her mine in the face of the world.

sp.speaker: "ORMEL.
sp.p: Then my miſery is complete.

sp.speaker: "ELIZA.
sp.p: It is as you ſuſpected, and your guardian means to become your huſband.

sp.speaker: "BENT.
sp.p: How many years has affection ſtruggled with prudence to prevent the ſecret eſcaping me! But I will delay my happineſs no longer.—I ſhall only inſiſt on the ſlut not praiſing me.—She muſt not ſhew her gratitude.—I'll overwhelm her with kindneſs, if ſhe will but promiſe to let nobody know it."

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: What accumulated misfortune! To-morrow, did he ſay? I ſhudder at the thought. What ſhall I do, Eliza?—What advice do you give me?

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: The only advice people in love ever take—to follow your own inclinations.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: Yet this dreadful ſtroke is not half ſo ſevere, as the cruel doubts I entertain of Warnford's affection—Oh, Eliza! I cannot ſupport the idea of his inconſtancy—You muſt go to him.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p:
And endeavour to paſs on him for
this Colonel Baton, who is expected from Pondicherri?

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: Yes, it will be the eaſieſt thing in the world—Warnford never ſaw him—You will at leaſt gain an introduction to him, and diſcover the ſtate of his heart—Nay, ſhould you even be diſcovered, the attempt will paſs for a jeſt.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Poor Warnford!—Heaven help him, if I begin to torment him; beſides, you know I am engaged in teazing my own lover, and really I think it is ſufficient amuſement for any reaſonable woman, whether married or ſingle, to plague one man at a time.

sp.speaker: "ORMEL.
sp.p: Pſhaw! if you would be ſerious.

sp.speaker: "ELIZA.
sp.p: Well, then, to be ſerious; ſuppoſe the real Frenchman ſhould arrive!"

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: Oh, my dear girl, do not oppoſe my impatience.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I am at your diſpoſal then from this moment; it will not be the firſt mad prank I have play'd, however, as theſe habiliments witneſs.

sp.speaker: "ORMEL.
sp.p: Remember your leſſon, that your name is Colonel Baton—that you are from Pondicherri—that you are to be at Muſhroom's houſe during your ſtay in Calcutta—that—

sp.speaker: "ELIZA.
sp.p: Never fear me, Madam."

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: I am ſure you will pardon the effects of my anxiety, when you conſider the ſituation of my heart; and yet amidſt all my uneaſineſs, I liſten to the ſweet accents of hope.

lg.l: Hope bids pleaſure ſmile anew,
And whiſpers that my lover's true:
Ah! while the tidings I receive,
I wiſh, but ſcarcely can believe.
Yet, tho' ideal be the bliſs,
No chance of happineſs I'll miſs.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Here comes my dear Henry—how fortunate!

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I cannot get this youth out of my head—the moſt exact reſemblance of her I love—

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: [aſide] Now for a good opportunity to enter into converſation with him.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I never heard of my dear girl having a brother. [ſeeing Eliza—aſide] The very perſon as I live—I'll ſpeak to him—You are lately from England, Sir?

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: [aſſuming the Scotch dialect] Yes, Sir, juſt arrieved, and on an errand which may be weel ſurpriſe ye:—What ſay ye to love ſending a mon to India? Dinna ye think I am the only inſtance o' th' kind?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I fear not, Sir. [ſighing.]

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I am thus circumſtanced.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: May be, then, our ſituation is exactly alike;—the object of my affactions is now in Bengal.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Would that I could ſay the ſame!—but the miſtreſs of my heart is in England.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: [aſide] How I long to contradict him!—May be than your miſtreſs wur nae kind to ye?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I do not complain of her.—If ſhe was in an error, ſhe muſt have already felt its effects but too ſeverely.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Generous man! [aſide.] But what way ha' ye borne ye're miſery?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: I have borne it as becomes a ſoldier—in ſilence.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: And wur it really ſorrow unmixed wie anger? wud na' an exclamation againſt the ſex break forth noo and than?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, if ſhe whom I love could but view my heart; it is an emblem of the glaſſy rivulet, on whoſe banks we have ſo often taken our melancholy walk; though a ſudden ſtorm may for a time efface her image from the ſurface, the ſucceeding calm faithfully reſtores the picture.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: But you forget aw circumſtance, to render the ſimile complete; neither the rivulet, nor the heart can preſerve the lady's picture in her abſence.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: You are to be envied, who can treat love with raillery.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Indeed you miſtake me.—I love wi an affaction equal to yours; I love ſa weel, that— [aſide] Heavens! what am I ſaying!—I forget what I have promiſed to Ormellina.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: You ſeem agitated, Sir.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p:
I am ſo indeed—I wuſht to ſay ſomething to ye which I canna noo explain—Yeur hond, Sir. Meet me at Captain Coromandel's in the evening.—Speer ye for ain Mr. M'Proteus;
—you wull find reaſon to flatter me wi the title of freend at leaſt.

lg.l: Oh! no accuſing ſigh ſhall riſe,
Of broken vows complaining;
Her error's paſt—reſentment dies,
And love's alone remaining.
Weak is the ſorrow, which by tears
Can ſtoop to court compaſſion,
Or fondly vain condolance hears,
That mockery of faſhion.
Oh! no accuſing ſigh, &c.
Why to the world my griefs impart:
The gay with ſcorn receive them:
Why wound with plaints the feeling heart,
Which would, but can't relieve them?
Oh! no accuſing ſigh ſhall riſe,
Of broken vows complaining;
Her error's paſt—reſentment dies,
And love's alone remaining.

div.head: SCENE, WARNFORD's Houſe.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p:
Poor maſſa! he be ſure in love; he walk about and talke to himſelf. I wonder if he love like poor Indian—He can't love better.—Sometime I ſigh by myſelf, and wiſh I was
grand Engliſh gentleman, to ride in my palanquin, and have great riche—and den I meet Dayda, and ſhe ſmile and ſay, dear Roſario, I love you;—and den I wiſh for no palanquin, no great riche—I ſo glad dat I be poor Roſario.

lg.l: When from Dayda dear I'm parting,
And I promiſe not to grieve;
When ſhe ſtop de ſigh juſt ſtarting,
And den twenty times take leave;
Oft my Dayda's grief I'm chiding,
Try to ſmile, and ſay good bye;
But while her ſtifled ſigh ſhe's hiding,
Still de tear come in my eye.
Tho' ſad thoughts my poor heart paining,
I remember when we meet,
De tear of abſence yet remaining
Make our meeting ſeem more ſweet,
As de dew-drop of de morning
Gliſten ven de dawn appear;
Love my Dayda's eyes adorning,
Smile more bright upon de tear.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: My maſter will wait on you immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Ah, don't let him hurry himſelf. The devil take this Muſhroom for bringing me here, and inſiſting on my being introduced to Warnford.—Curſe his civility.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: [without] Come along, Colonel. [Enters] Zounds, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: "TWIST.
sp.p: Why, really, it is very kind of you, to inſiſt on my being introduced to Mr. Warnford;—but—

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: But what?—I tell you he'll like to hear you talk of his father, with whom you were ſo well acquainted when you viſited England.

sp.speaker: "TWIST.
sp.p: Then he'll be plaguily diſappointed—for I'm reſolved not to open my lips on that ſubject. I hate old ſtories—they are a ſhocking bore.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: Well, I muſt leave you for the preſent; however, I'll endeavour to find Warnford, and ſend him to you.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: What will become of me?—Egad, I find impudence, like corks to a bad ſwimmer, may tempt a man dangerouſly out of his depth. I wonder whether this Warnford is apt to be choleric.—Zounds, if he ſhould deal in kicking!—I ſhould like to ſee whether he has a fighting face; if one could get a ſquint at him through any compaſſionate window, or the crevice of a door—or—

lg.l: Hark! I hear! I hear him coming;
At each ſtep I quake for fear:
Oh! a plague on this curſt mumming!
This fool's coat will coſt me dear.
Yet, ſince there's no eſcaping,
His fury I muſt dare,
And, other heroes apeing,
Take courage from deſpair.
If I could but courage muſter,
Juſt to bounce a bit or ſo;
But in what way ſhall I bluſter?
Piſtol, ſword, or boxing blow.
Ha, ha! ſa, ſa! or ſo, ſo, boh!—no.
At the thought I quake with terror:
Why did I this ſcheme purſue?
Oh! too late I find my error;
What the devil ſhall I do?
I muſt all his fury dare,
Gath'ring courage from deſpair.
Tho' 'tis brave to dare a beating,
Wiſer 'tis to run away;
But, alas! there's no retreating,
Here muſt I be bound to ſtay.
Hark! I hear him! what the devil ſhall I do?
Hark! again I hear him coming;
At each ſtep I quake with fear:
Oh! a plague on this curſt mumming!
Why did I this ſcheme purſue?
Hark! again I hear him coming:
What the devil ſhall I do?
I muſt all his fury dare,
Gath'ring courage from deſpair.

div.stage: Enter ELIZA dreſt as Colonel BATON, with ROSARIO.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p:
Tell Monſieur Warnford dat his friend
le Colonel Baton vait to pay his reſpect.— [Exit Roſario] Poor Henry!—I declare he has made me almoſt as penſive as himſelf—There is ſomething very contagious in the melancholy of the man we love.—But now for my French character: ſo exit love for the preſent, and vive la bagatelle.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [coming forward] Here he is;—I am not ſo much afraid of him as I expected to be.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Hey day, whom have we here? [Twiſt comes forward; they bow to each other, and teſtify mutual ſurpriſe] Coromandel's taylor in maſquerade, by all that's ridiculous. [aſide]

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [aſide] The little lady-like paſſenger, who came on board our ſhip!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient—I am extremely anxious to pay my reſpects to Colonel Baton, if he will do me the honour to name himſelf.

sp.speaker: "ELIZA.
sp.p: Sir, I— [aſide] What can that fellow mean? He is dreſſed as if he meant to perſonate—

sp.speaker: "TWIST.
sp.p: [aſide] Egad, I'm fairly plunged in over head and ears: if I do ſink, it ſha'n't be without a ſtruggle however."

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Sair, I'ave de honneur to announce myſelf.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Yes, Sair, I'ave de honor to announce myſelf.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your impatience to announce yourſelves is highly flattering to me; but pray which is Colonel Baton?

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: C'eſt moi.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: I am the colonel, Sir.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: A moſt ſingular incident! When you are both inclined to be ſerious—

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Serieux!

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Aye, Sir—ſerious.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Nay, I beg pardon; if you are diſpoſed for a tilting bout, I'll interrupt you no longer—Three perſons form an aukward party on theſe occaſions. [aſide] Theſe are a couple of ſcoundrels.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Vera extraordinaire to treat a me dus, Sair; moi, your old friend.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: "At leaſt, Sir, you're an old friend with a new face." [To Twiſt] You are alſo an old friend of mine.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I have as great a regard for you as I had for your father.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! You will pardon my caution, gentlemen; but it is ſo difficult to diſtinguiſh one's real friends.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Ah! ſans doute.—I dare ſay vid your pleaſant brutale manners you 'ave never yet find any friend at all.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: Except yourſelf, Sir; and you know you were pleaſed to honour me with that title, though you had never ſeen me.

sp.speaker: "ELIZA.
sp.p: Yes, Sair, for dat vara raiſon, becauſe I had not ſeen you."

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [aſide] I'faith, the little fellow acts it rarely. [attempting to imitate Eliza's manner] I can't manage it half ſo well.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Your are witty, Sir.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—I believe, Sir, you grow a little angry.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Perhaps I may, Sir—and then—

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Ah! pray pleaſe to be angry—It will amuſe me. Ah! it be ſo charmant to ſee Jack Roaſt Beef ven he be enragé, like de grand ſtupid Lion at de Tour of Londres, ven dey give him little poke, and rouze him up, and make him roar.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir!

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! trot about—dancez, s'il vous plait, plus vite, faſter, faſter— [ſinging] Malbrouk s'en va t'en guerre.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [to Twiſt] What d'ye mean by that, Sir? 'Sdeath, I'll—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Mrs. Muſhroom, Sir.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: How abſurd to ſuffer theſe fools to ruffle my temper!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. MUSHROOM [ſpeaking as ſhe comes on].

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Warnford, I am come to quarrel with you. Hey-day! you're engaged, I ſee.— [aſide] What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: I would introduce Colonel Baton to you, if I knew which it was of theſe two gentlemen. "But I ſee it is unneceſſary; you ſeem to be acquainted with them both."

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p:
Mr. Warnford, a word with you—Aſk me not who or what I am; "for I won't tell you" I came hither to ſerve you. Do
not interrupt, but anſwer me. Can you ſubmit to ſee Ormellina married to another, to her guardian, Colonel Bentley?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: I tremble at the thought.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: This evening then muſt determine your fate; ſhe will be at Captain Coromandel's—I'll meet you there, and pilot you to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [coming forward with Twiſt] I believe, Sir, you had better, like a falling miniſter, retire to prevent you being turned out.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: I will, Ma'am—but then the worſt of it is, I muſt retire without a penſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I vow the hiſtory of the two laſt hours would furniſh an additional ſtory for Ovid's Metamorphoſes.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide] If the information ſhould be falſe.— [to her] Very true, indeed, Madam, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I ſent you a letter this morning—I find, however, it was not received.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: But then for what purpoſe ſhould he deceive me? [aſide]—No, Ma'am—not received."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Now I own my idea—

sp.speaker: WARN.
sp.p: Oh, Ormellina! [aſide:—To Mrs. M.] A—a—yes, Madam, that is my idea.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what may your ideas be? For your echo converſation does not betray any ſigns of them.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Pardon, pardon, my dear Mrs. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
Come, come, you are agitated by the news you have heard from the gentleman who has now left you, Mr. M'Proteus
— [aſide] He has been mentioning the contents of my letter.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: I am ſo, indeed.— [aſide] Surely ſhe is apprized of Ormellina's intended marriage.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I know not what he meant by ſo whimſically aſſuming the dreſs of a French officer—but undoubtedly he came on purpoſe to give you the information.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: He ſaid ſo indeed."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I imagine M'Proteus told you he ſaw my letter to you.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: You wrote me a letter then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, appointing an interview—I could not reſt till I explained to you.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide] Yes, yes, ſhe knows of Colonel Bentley's deſign of marrying Ormellina.— [to her] Generous woman! [kiſſing her hand.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: But a ridiculous miſtake preventing my letter reaching you—I am now come in perſon to inform you—

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: On my knees let me thank you for your condeſcenſion—Love alone like mine—

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Love like mine—Is it my turn to be Echo now, Mr. Warnford?"

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [without] Where is he, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: My huſband's voice!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: His arrival is very fortunate indeed—I dare ſay he will lend us his aſſiſtance in any ſcheme to effect my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Nay, Ma'am, if he is ignorant of the circumſtance, and you wiſh him to remain ſo—

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
Upon my life, Warnford, you jumble jeſt and earneſt in ſuch a manner, that
I don't know what to make of you—But I muſt retire—So get rid of Muſhroom as ſoon as you can.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Jumble jeſt and earneſt!—"I am ſure I ſee no jeſt in the matter."

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Zounds! what's become of the Colonel? Off!—Eh!—Ah! you had ſome female viſitor, I ſuppoſe?—Come, tell the truth—Nay, no ceremony with me—You know I hate ceremony—I was bred a low fellow, and ſo I have always remained—Not a farthing the poorer for that, by the bye. But I abhor gentility.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Why, Sir, as for the Colonel—

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Come, come, I know you don't like him—He is not genteel enough for you—But I wiſh you hadn't packed him off ſo ſoon—There is Captain Coromandel below ſtairs, who longed to ſee him.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Who? Captain Coromandel? Excuſe me for a moment.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Hey-day! What's in the wind now? Egad he takes my advice, and makes no ceremony with me, indeed! I fancy there is not much ceremony between him and my jade of a wife neither—I find ſhe is ſomewhere about the houſe at this moment; and I begin to doubt whether her letter was meant for that booby French Colonel. Let me read it once more. [ſits down and takes the letter from his pocket]

div.stage: Enter Mrs. MUSHROOM behind; comes forward on tiptoe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: All is quiet! I hope Warnford has ſent my huſband off. [ſhe ſees Muſhroom, and ſhrieks.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Ah! my dear, I know I always have your good wiſhes—You did not expect to meet me here, I dare ſay; but I believe there is a ſecret ſympathy between us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: A ſecret ſympathy then it muſt be; for I have never found it out.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Then I have the advantage of you, my love—But, indeed, I am ever making diſcoveries, and indebted to you for them all too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: And yet you have not profited by what a wiſe man would deem the moſt important of my diſcoveries. You know, my dear, I have often, with a faithful pencil, given you a whole length picture of yourſelf.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: And, I fancy, my dear, you have paid particular attention to finiſhing my head properly—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Your attempts at wit, Mr. Muſhroom, are a kind of hyſterical diſorder, which creates univerſal pity, and makes no one laugh but yourſelf—Not that I deny you ſome merit.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Aye, aye, what may that be?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
You have the peculiar happineſs of reconciling us even to your ill-manners. They are a ſet of bad features diſtorted into a pleaſant caricature. Abſurdity, your conſtant friend, tinges even your impertinence with folly, and ſaves you from chaſtiſement, by rendering
you ridiculous. Is the picture complete, my life?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, my ſoul, and now for yours.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Huſh! here is ſomebody coming.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] That's unlucky—I had one of the ſevereſt things at my tongue's end—However—I'll ſave it for our next quarrel.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: My dear Coromandel, you give me new life: you ſay you've ſeen Ormellina!

sp.speaker: "COROM.
sp.p: Ay, and have removed all her ſcruples. You ſhall ſee her this evening—and—but we are not alone— [to Muſhroom and wife] My old friends, I rejoice to ſee you."

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: There is a pair whom Hymen has bound with wreaths of roſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] I'faith, then the roſes have dropt off, and left nothing but thorns.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: My experience of wedlock, Mr. Warnford, leads me to wiſh all my friends married.— [aſide] It is ſome comfort to have companions in one's misfortunes.

sp.speaker: COROM.
sp.p: Aye, aye, that's right, Muſhroom.

lg.head: QUARTETTO.
lg.stage: WARNFORD, COROMANDEL, Mr. and Mrs. MUSHROOM.

lg.l: Hymen's delights all other joys outweigh—
What does my dear—my huſband ſay?
With ſuch a wife, how happy muſt he be!
Bleſt in ſuch pleaſing bonds, who would be free?
What ſays my friend—
What does the happy huſband ſay?
Tol lol de rol, is all I ſay.

div.head: SCENE, COROMANDEL's Houſe.

sp.speaker: "STANM.
sp.p: I WONDER this Mr. M'Proteus is not come yet. He certainly can tell me ſome news of my Eliza.

sp.speaker: "COROM.
sp.p: From love and ſhipwreck Heaven preſerve me! Why, what's the matter with the man?

sp.speaker: "STANM.
sp.p: I cannot help it—I own myſelf unfit for ſociety.

lg.l: "What avails it to me that ſo fair
"Was Eliza, ſo gentle and kind,
"Since fortune was deaf to my pray'r.
"And my love to another conſign'd?
"O'er whatever new objects ariſe,
"The dark ſhade of ſorrow is caſt,
"And memory buſily tries
"Their likeneſs to trace with the paſt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: "If the ſtroke of misfortune I meet,
"With vengeance redoubled it falls,
"When fancy, with malice replete,
"The hour of our parting recals:
"For a moment would peace be my gueſt,
"Remembrance, my bittereſt foe,
"Reminds me that once I was bleſt,
"To plunge me the deeper in woe.

div.stage: Enter COROMANDEL, WARNFORD, and Colonel BATON.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Once more, Colonel, welcome to my houſe: I congratulate you on your eſcape from old Muſhroom's: I find you ſuffer'd ſome indignities there.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Ce n'eſt rien—Ve people of gallanterie tink dat litel difficulté make de plaiſure of de conqueſt greater; dat Madame Muſhroom be adorable; [aſide] ſhe love me to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Ah! Colonel, you are a happy man—but I am perſuaded that your own happineſs will not render you forgetful that our friend here is not ſo.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Sair, ven I do ſo I vill renounce my contrée: I rejoice to hear de accents of happineſs from all around me; de harmonie delight my heart, and I join de chorus.—But if von ſtring be out of tune—if one litel ſigh of miſerie reach my ear—ah! all de concert be ſpoil pour moi.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, I perceive the goodneſs of your heart; I give you credit for your kind intentions.

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: No, Sair, I vill have no credit—I vill pay vat I owe; you be my friend—you vant my aſſiſtance—I can give it to you—and I love to pay my debt. You ſay Madame Ormellina conſent to run avay vid you?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Yes, my perſuaſions have prevail'd on her to ſeek an aſylum in a foreign ſettlement, where the power and influence of her guardian cannot reach us.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: [to Baton] I find your friend the French captain fails for Pondicherri early tomorrow morning; I have contrived that the lovers ſhall be ſafely convey'd on ſhipboard this evening—and then—

sp.speaker: Col. BAT.
sp.p: Dé ſighs of love vill fill deir ſails—Cupidon vill be deir pilot—Hymen vill ſtand at de helm—and I vill go and ſettle every ting with the Capitaine. Morbleau, I viſh I had tought of it before; I dare ſay Madame Muſhroom vou'd be of de partie; or if ſhe vou'd not go, perhaps dat litel girl dat laugh ſo—her fille de chambre—Bleſs me, I ſhou'd like to run avay vid ſomebody.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Hark! ſome of your viſitors are come already.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Then I had better join them, to prevent ſuſpicion. Remember that when Ormellina ſteals away from the company, ſhe is to conceal herſelf in the garden, till every thing is ready for your elopement.

lg.l: Long have hope and fear, contending,
Ruled by turns my troubled breaſt;
This bleſt hour, the conflict ending,
Shall to my flutt'ring heart give reſt.
And yet, alas! ſhould hope deceive;—
No, no, her impulſe I'll believe:
Hence, coward doubts, away;
I'll not be importuned:
On this auſpicious day
My ſoul to joy's attuned.

sp.p: 'Sdeath, here comes my torment, Mrs. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Oh, Warnford! I am ſo glad to meet with you at laſt. Do you know my huſband is abſolutely jealous of you.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Jealous of me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: He watches me ſo narrowly, that I have made an excuſe for bringing Lucy with me, to obſerve him, and prevent his coming upon us unawares.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Really you ſurpriſe me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I dare ſay I do; I don't know any thing in your conduct and mine, which could have given riſe to Mr. Muſhroom's ſuſpicions; though he pretends to ſay our mutual attachment is very apparent.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: I begin to perceive the drift of theſe ingenious reflections.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Perhaps, indeed, relying too far on the purity of my intentions, my unſuſpecting temper may have betrayed me into a levity of manner; or perhaps (pardon the ſuppoſition), but perhaps you, in a convivial moment, might have ſpoken of me in ſuch terms as often give birth to ſcandal.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide] I'll teaze her—No never, as I recollect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
[aſide] How provoking! Come, come, Warnford, I know a man, without any
diſhonourable intention, might, in ſpeaking o a lady, ſay, "Egad, ſhe is a fine woman"—Her huſband is a horrid fellow—and if ſhe were to throw herſelf in my way—

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: A moſt curious catechiſm [aſide]—I aſſure you, Madam, I never ſpoke thus of you in my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: What an inſenſible creature! [aſide]—Though Mr. Muſhroom ſeems to lay the greateſt ſtreſs on what happened the other evening at my houſe: You were ſilly enough to attempt to kiſs my hand; and I was ſilly enough to let you. He ſays your eyes ſpoke a thouſand tender things; to which I only replied, I did not obſerve it; and, as I told him, I am ſure you meant nothing at all—Now did you?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: A home queſtion, by my ſoul—there is no parrying this [aſide]. My dear Madam.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Ma'am, Ma'am! juſt as we expected, my maſter miſs'd you from the room below, and is coming ſoftly up the back ſtairs, in hopes of ſurpriſing you and Mr. Warnford together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Deuce take his curioſity!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: It is very impertinent, to be ſure—This way, my dear Ma'am.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Don't go out at that door, Sir; it leads to the garden, where you will be ſurely diſcovered—make haſte into this room—here is the key of the door—I'll match the old gentleman, I'll warrant him. [Mrs. Muſhroom and Warnford go in, and Lucy locks the door, and tries if her key will fit the lock of the other door.]

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: The ſame key fits both locks; that is lucky indeed.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] Hey day, gone already! why How can they have eſcaped?—That jade Lucy here?—then there is miſchief ſtirring— [to her] How the devil did you come here? and what are you fidgetting about at that door?

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Dear Sir—you—you—really your queſtions confuſe one ſo.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Indeed! well, I didn't think any queſtion whatever could have confuſed you—however, I'll ſpare your bluſhes for the ſake of their novelty—ſo open that door for me. [Lucy ſetting her back againſt the door of the empty room.]

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: What door, Sir?—this?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, that—I ſuppoſe you have the key.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: I have the key, to be ſure, Sir; but hadn't you better go into the other room.—Indeed, Sir, you will find nobody here.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Huſſey, Huſſey! you're in league with my wife.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Who, Sir, would not be partial to ſo kind a miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, i'faith, I believe ſhe's a kind miſtreſs to half my acquaintance—but open the door, I tell you.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Pray take my advice, Sir;—indeed, if you go in you'll repent it.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Open the door, I ſay.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if it muſt be ſo.— [She opens the door, Muſhroom goes in, and ſhe turns the key upon him.]

div.stage: She then opens the other door, and enter Mrs. MUSHROOM and WARNFORD.
div.p: Well, Madam, what do you think of me now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Words cannot expreſs what I think of you.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: That is exactly my caſe, Lucy, and therefore let this ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Adieu then till to-morrow—I ſhall expect to ſee you.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: If I am in Calcutta, Madam, you may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [within] Open the door—Zounds, you have lock'd me in.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you would not take good advice when I offered it. I ſaid you would repent it.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Come, I know my wife has bribed you—But I'll pay you double what ſhe gave you.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you ought to be puniſhed for your unkind ſuſpicions. What reaſon now can you have for thinking—

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Pſhaw! what ſignifies arguing through a key-hole? Releaſe me, and truſt to my generoſity.

sp.speaker: LUCY.
sp.p: Well, Sir, for once I will— [aſide to Mrs. Muſhroom] Here, Madam, I commit my priſoner to your care.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: [coming out.] Aye, aye, I'll reward you, and as for my wife—

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Here I am, my dear huſband, in the obedient diſcharge of my duty. How agreeable it is to meet thus unexpectedly!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, but it would be rather more agreeable to part unexpectedly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Come, come, Muſhroom, we have quarrelled till we have nothing more to ſay. Let us agree by way of variety.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: With all my heart, I know you like variety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Let me ſee then how gallantly you can hand me back to the company.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Agreed. [takes her hand]

sp.speaker: "COROM.
sp.p: Our friends are quite impatient for you.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: I have been taking a ramble over this part of your houſe, Mr. Coromandel, and admiring the elegance with which it is fitted up.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Muſhroom is very fond of rambling ſometimes." Let us go and make our apologies. Take care, my dear, how you walk—you know you are very apt to trip.

head.hi: SCENE changes to the Garden—The Entrance of a Walk overſhadowed with Trees, is ſeen on the right Hand.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
