sp.p: Give me joy, Coromandel; our ſcheme has ſucceeded beyond expectation—a pretended head-ache afforded my dear girl an opportunity of quitting the company, and Colonel Bentley was the firſt to urge her to go home.

sp.speaker: COROM.
sp.p: Behold the place of your retreat, Madam. That walk, which I formed into a bower to ſhield me from the rays of the midday ſun. This is the only entrance to it, and I will ſend Roſario to watch if any one approach.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Still ſo penſive!—Surely, my charming Ormellina will no longer doubt my truth.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: No, Warnford, you have convinced me that I need not bluſh to declare my affection for you. Let guilt be the parent of ſhame—I feel none in avowing my attachment to a man of honour—the firſt and only attachment of which my heart was ever ſuſceptible.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Delightful confeſſion.

lg.l: "Then no more, my deareſt bleſſing,
"Let pale Doubt our hopes annoy;
"For conſtancy, each fear repreſſing,
"Twines for us her wreath of joy.
"O no more, my deareſt bleſſing,
"May pale Doubt our hopes annoy:
"But conſtancy, each fear repreſſing,
"Twine for us her wreath of joy.
"Love deſigns to be our guide
"To bliſs, thro' Hymen's fane.
"Oh may no ill betide,
"Nor may we ſeek in vain:
"And yet, tho' ne'er aſunder,
"Our guide and us we find.
"Ah! ſhoued we ſtray, no wonder—
"That guide, alas! is blind.
"His aim too true we find,
"His blindneſs too deſpiſe;
"For tho' the archer's blind,
"His ſhaft unerring flies.
"If Love be but our guide
"To bliſs, thro' Hymen's fane,
"Then ſhall no ill betide,
"Nor ſhall we ſigh in vain."

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Here are the turtles—This is what I ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: I conſider Colonel Bentley as my deareſt friend—He has a claim to my utmoſt gratitude and eſteem—But you have my heart, and I ſhudder at the idea of mocking him with a ſhadow of affection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] All ſoul and ſentiment—not a ſingle vile, earthly idea abour her, I warrant.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: However the Colonel may be blinded by paſſion, I know him to be honourable, and I know he will one day thank me for having put it out of his power to be unjuſt—But you ought to quit me for the preſent, Warnford; the Colonel will wonder at your abſence.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: I go, my love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [aſide] And I'll ſtay, my love, to ſee the end of this romance.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: Pray leave me—Conſider—on this hour depends our fate.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p:
I obey—"And may the dawning preſage of happineſs, which now revives my
ſoul, ſmile on us with meridian ſplendour when next we meet."

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: This is, indeed, an eventful moment for me.

lg.l: Thus, juſt eſcaped the ſtorm,
The mariner eſpies
Black clouds the dawn deform,
And hide again the ſkies.
Trembling with wild diſmay,
He views the morning's gloom
Contending with the day
That muſt decide his doom.

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: Ah! Roſario, I'm glad you are come—I am ſure I hear ſomebody talking with Mr. Warnford—follow him, and liſten, Roſario; I will retreat here in the meanwhile

div.stage: OMELLINA goes to the entrance of the arbour.

sp.p: Heavens! ſome one is conceal'd here already: how unfortunate!

div.stage: Enter ROSARIO [and goes to the arbour].

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Need not be frighten'd, Miſſee Ormellina; it be only Captain Coromandel talk with my maſſa—Don't be melancholy, Miſſee Ormellina; I be ſure my maſſa love you dearly. Roſario will ſing a little ſong to amuſe you.

lg.l: Now de ſultry day be paſt,
And pleaſant night be come at laſt;
Oh! how ſweet abroad to ſtray,
While on de wave de moon-beams play!
While de gentle winds quite pleaſe,
Wake and whiſper 'mong de trees;
Teaching lovers in deir walk
Softly like demſelves to talk.
Now de ſultry day, &c.
Angry paſſions every one
Leave us with the ſcorching ſun:
Love, now like de morn appear,
And gaily ſmile ſo bright and clear.
Now de ſultry, &c.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Come hither, my good boy, I want to ſpeak to you. Will you do me a favour?

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Roſario would love dearly to do you a favour, you ſay ſo kind.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Be ſo good as to ſtep to Mr. Stanmore, and tell him a gentleman waits here to ſpeak with him; whiſper to him, Roſario, ſo that nobody may overhear you.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: No money, Sir. I ſhall like to oblige you; but it be no oblige ven you pay me—rather you keep money, and ſay to me, thank ye.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: And I will thank thee, Roſario, as I ought.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Ah, ha!—Voila mon homme— [comes forward ſoftly, and taps Eliza on the ſhoulder] Serviteur. I am told, Sair, you call yourſelf Colonel Baton.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I—I have anſwer'd to that name, Sir.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Den I preſume, Sair, you be officier in de French ſervice, by your vite cockade.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Sir, I—I, yes, Sir; I wear a white cockade—I admire it extremely.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: So do I, Sair.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I am very glad you like it—I—

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: And I muſt 'ave it, Sair.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Have my cockade, Sir! Bleſs me, that is a little extraordinary.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Monſieur. [angrily]

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Well, Sir, there it is—If you have taken any fancy to the hat, Sir, it is at your ſervice. [aſide] I wiſh Henry were come.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: [tears the cockade from Eliza's hat] Now, Sair, you 'ave no mark of de livree of my ſovereign—I tell you dat you be villain, poltroon.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I think it is very abſurd for us to cut throats about a piece of white ribbon—ſo—

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: I know dat I do you too much honeur to fight you. [drawing his ſword]

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Then I am ſure, Sir, I don't deſire any more honour than is my due.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Allons, defend yourſelf.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I wiſh I could, Sir.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: [preſſing on Eliza with his ſword] Combatez! combatez! Monſieur.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: No, Sir, you have diſhonoured my reputation, by calling me a coward, and I will not fight till I have cleared my character. Pray, Sir, don't be ſo violen. [aſide] What ſhall I do? I muſt avow myſelf.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Repondez ſcelerat!—anſwer me—do you deſerve the name of man?

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir—I am—

sp.speaker: BA ON.
sp.p: Parlez—vite.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I am—

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Vat be you?

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: I am— [ſeeing Stanmore, who enters at the moment] Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Heavens! that voice—no longer diſtinguiſhed by the Scotch accent—I—

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Here is my champion, Colonel—Surely he will defend a life which I have riſked for the joy of ſeeing him once more; and which, from this moment, ſhall be devoted to repair the wrongs he has ſuffered.

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: [embracing her] My life! my ſoul! my deareſt Eliza.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: [aſide] My dear Eliza! Oh ho! [to her] Madame, vil you pardon my miſtake? Dere be de cockade. Venever you like to go into de armie again, I hope to 'ave de honneur of be your commanding officer.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: You ſee, Colonel, I have engaged with another commander, and I am ſure you are too much a man of honour to wiſh I ſhould ever deſert.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: [aſide] Ah! dat laſt glance at me mean ſomething. I have catch her too.

sp.speaker: COROM.
sp.p: I need not aſk whether an explanation has taken place.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Indeed, it has been as ſhort as ſweet, thanks to Colonel Baton's mode of frightening one out of a ſecret.

sp.speaker: COROM.
sp.p: I am ſorry, however, the ſecret has made ſo much noiſe. You have poſitively alarmed the houſe. Colonel Bentley, and our whole party, are coming into the garden, to ſee what is the matter.

sp.speaker: BATON.
sp.p: Den I muſt retire for de preſent.

sp.speaker: ELIZ.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, when you retreat, I think my courage will not ſuffer by following your example.

sp.speaker: COROM.
sp.p: Poor Ormellina will be ſcared out of her wits. [goes to the arbour where Mrs. Muſhroom is concealed] Don't be alarmed, my dear Madam—Nobody knows you are there, except Warnford and myſelf.

div.stage: Enter WARNFORD, Col. BENTLEY, and MUSHROOM.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Well, Coromandel, what the devil has produced all this clatter?—ſome of your ſpoilt ſervants, I ſuppoſe, at their gambols—aye—all the effects of your fooliſh good-nature.

sp.speaker: "COROM.
sp.p: Come, Colonel, let us have no more of this affectation.—You to abuſe goodnature—you, in whoſe compoſition the milk of human kindneſs is the chief ingredient."

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p:
"Sir, I deny it—I diſclaim it—'Tis on the milk of human kindneſs, knavery thrives, Sir."—I rejoice in my ill-humour; it
is a fortification raiſed around me by nature, to guard me from ruin.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Don't tell me of your fortifications—A tear from virtue in diſtreſs would make a practicable breach in one minute.

sp.speaker: "BENT.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir, I take your compliments very ill; and if you perſiſt in your curſed civility, you will oblige me to quit your houſe.

sp.speaker: "CORO.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Colonel, rather than offend you, I will allow you to be as bad as you pleaſe; I will acknowledge you to be unfeeling, uncharitable, cynical, moroſe—In ſhort, one of the moſt diſagreeable men I am acquainted with."

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Pſhaw! a fig for your arguments; let us go and finiſh our bottle.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: No, no; if we muſt have a bottle, let us have it here. It is a fine evening, and I like variety—you know I am whimſical.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Dear Sir, conſider the abſurdity.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: I always was reckoned abſurd, and I wiſh to act up to my character.

sp.speaker: "CORO.
sp.p: Well, but Colonel—

sp.speaker: "BENT.
sp.p: Mr. Coromandel, obſtinacy is my favourite virtue—on this ſpot I either take a glaſs of wine, or take my leave—ſo make your choice."

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: "Then, Sir, my choice is made." Bring wine immediately. [to a ſervant.]

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide to Coromandel] 'Sdeath, Coromandel, are you mad?

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: [aſide to Warnford] Pſhaw! give the child his rattle, and he'll ſoon be tired of it. [bottles and glaſſes brought in.]

div.stage: Enter a Servant, and whiſpers Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Colonel Baton wants me, do you ſay? deſire him to walk this way—here are none but friends.

div.stage: Enter TWIST [ſtill diſguiſed as Colonel Baton].

sp.p: Ah, Colonel.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Huſh, my good Sir,—I—I—I thought you were alone—I'll call on you another time.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Hey day, Colonel, you ſeem confoundedly frightened at ſomething.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Sudden ſurpriſe, Sir, that's all. [aſide] Here is Coromandel and Warnford—I ſhall be blown preſently.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Oh, oh! the ſurpriſe of meeting your old friend Colonel Bentley ſo unexpectedly?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; really it overcomes me. [going.]

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: I'faith, you ſha'n't leave us.

sp.speaker: "CORO.
sp.p: [aſide to Warnford] There is that raſcal, Twiſt, diſguiſed in Baton's clothes.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide to Coromandel] Let him alone—we have a more ſerious object to engage our attention."

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: [to Muſhroom] Pray which is my old acquaintance Colonel Bentley?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: There he ſits. How aſtoniſhingly altered he muſt be to have eſcaped your recollection! I'faith, he looks at you as if he had never ſeen you before.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p:
So he does—and—and it abſolutely diſtreſſes me. Let me tell you, Mr. Muſhroom, that to be forgotten thus by one's friends—but my
feelings overcome me—I had rather go, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Indeed I ſha'n't ſuffer you to go. I will ſeat you next to Colonel Bentley, without telling him who you are.—It will be a very good joke.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Heigh-ho! Well, if it muſt be ſo; but, upon my ſoul, I am not in a joking humour. [ſits down.]

sp.speaker: "BENT.
sp.p: I declare I am quite in love with our ſituation; this is an excellent place for a catch.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: And there is another excellent place for a catch in the houſe—'Tis a moſt bewitching room—when one is once in it, one hardly knows how to get out again—Eh, Mr. Warnford.

sp.speaker: "BENT.
sp.p: There is ſome hidden meaning in all this."

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: "Oh, yes, 'tis the faſhion to have things hidden in this houſe; aye, and in this garden too; for" I am much miſtaken if I had not the glimpſe of a petticoat in that arbour juſt now. [aſide.] My loving wife, moſt likely.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide] 'Sdeath, I muſt explain the truth, to keep him quiet. [whiſpers Muſhroom.]

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: What does all this myſterious converſation ſignify?

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Why, it ſignifies that we have not yet had wine enough to underſtand each other properly.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p:
[aſide to Warnford] And you ſay Ormellina is really concealed there?—Egad, I
could have ſworn it had been my wife; for I did ſuſpect you, Warnford. However, leave me to bring the Colonel to reaſon. [aſide to Colonel Bentley.] A word with you.—I ſuppoſe you don't know that a particular friend of yours is in that arbour; but, indeed, you have no great knack in finding out your friends—Eh, Colonel. [to Twiſt.]

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: This may be wit, Mr. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Aye, and truth into the bargain.—I tell you as a fact, that Warnford has concealed Ormellina in that arbour; by the bye, he muſt not know I told you ſo. "[aſide] I have long owed Warnford a good turn, and now I think I have paid him."

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: [aſide] Juſt as I could wiſh. I long to embrace the ſpirited young rogue.

sp.speaker: "MUSH.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, after what I have explained to you, your ſuſpicions muſt of courſe ceaſe. [aſide to him] You don't ſeem to be angry."

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: "Zounds, Sir, but I am, and very angry too." Mr. Coromandel, I have particular reaſons for wiſhing to know who is in that retired walk.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: My dear Colonel, the requeſt is ſo ſtrange!

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt perſiſt in it. I charge that gentleman [pointing to Warnford] with having meanly concealed—

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p:
Meanly concealed! No man, but yourſelf, Colonel Bentley, dare uſe the expreſſion. If I have had recourſe to artifice, it was in an honourable cauſe; in defence of beauty and virtue, which claimed my protection againſt the
man who dares to become my accuſer.—I own a lady is there.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis very hard a man can't hide a pretty woman in a corner, with her own conſent, without the place being ſearched, as if it contained ſmuggled goods.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: That lady was concealed there by me—my warmeſt hopes have been crowned with her conſent to elope with me this evening—Her heart is mine, and I will defend the poſſeſſion of it with my life. [goes to the arbour, and Mrs. Muſhroom comes out]—Confuſion!

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Why, what the devil does this mean, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Really, my dear, you had better aſk Mr. Warnford's ſervant, Roſario—he watch'd me in my concealment, and, I ſuppoſe, can explain the reaſons why he did ſo.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: What's the matter, Warnford? You have only had recourſe to artifice in an honourable cauſe, in defence of beauty and virtue, which claimed your protection.—By the bye, I don't recollect that ever I offered any violence to Mrs. Muſhroom's delicacy.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, Mr. Warnford, that you have uſed me curſedly ill.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: I don't ſee that, Muſhroom—you know 'tis very hard a man can't hide a pretty woman in a corner, with her own conſent.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Roſario!

Come hither, blockhead; go inſtantly to the lady whom you watched in that arbour—"preſent my compliments," and requeſt ſhe will
favour me with one minute's private converſation here.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: [aſide] Poor Miſs Ormellina will be ſo afraid:—before all dis company, Sir?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Tell her I ſhall be alone.—Obey my orders inſtantly, Roſario. Now gentlemen, "we ſhall have this myſtery explained—I flatter myſelf Mrs. Muſhroom will not refuſe me an explanation, and I am content that yourſelves ſhall witneſs it."—Retire into that very arbour which has been the ſource of our embarraſſment, and from thence you may overhear our converſation. [Exeunt all but Warnford into the arbour.]

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: This is ſome trick of that tormenting woman, and ſhe deſerves to be expoſed.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Is all ſafe, maſſa? All gentlemen gone?

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: You ſee I am alone.

sp.speaker: ROSA.
sp.p: Den Miſſee Ormellina may come here. [Retire up.]

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Oh, Warnford, what have. I not endured for this laſt half hour!

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: [aſide] 'Sdeath, how unlucky!—the Colonel will overhear every word.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: By the ſtrangeſt accident, I was deprived of the retreat we had agreed upon, and have been waiting in the garden—

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: Pray forbear—this is not a proper time"—

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p:
"Well, then let us be gone. Colonel Baton is now in the garden." A guide is
ready to conduct us to the ſhip, and, in ſhort, every obſtacle to our eſcape is removed.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: [comes down] No, Ormellina, there is ſtill an obſtacle to your eſcape.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: There can be none, Sir, while that lady conſents to be mine.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, young man, that obſtacle is my authority—the authority of a father.

sp.speaker: ORM.
sp.p: Gracious Heaven!

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Yes, Ormellina, this accident has forced the ſecret from me, which a regard for your welfare has for ſo many years buried in my boſom [embracing her] "As for you, Warnford, you are not much pleaſed with this diſcovery, I take it."—Look ye, Sir; zounds, if I were to give way to my feelings upon this occaſion—but I will repreſs them—I ſhall content myſelf with telling you, that you need not flatter yourſelf with any hopes of eloping with my daughter, and that effectually to prevent the moſt diſtant chance of your repeating ſo abominable an attempt, I am fixed and determined to give my conſent for your marrying her to-morrow.

sp.speaker: WARNF.
sp.p: Generous friend!—how ſhall I thank you?

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: By making a good huſband to my laughter, you rogue—that's the beſt way of thanking me.
Ah, Stanmore, give us joy.

lg.l: Gratitude, for utterance ſtriving,
Finds the aid of language vain.
Drooping hope once more reviving,
Calls me back to life again.
Friendſhip too his tribute brings,
Joining Love in feſtive lay;
Of conſtancy the praiſe he ſings,
And hails her bright triumphal day.
While wedlock's ſweets enjoying,
Nine couples out of ten,
Leſt ſweets ſhould prove too cloying,
Quarrel now and then.
Oh fie!
You ſhould have ſpoke before:
To Hymen's bonds conſenting,
Why fright me half repenting?
I vow I'll hear no more.
OR. Huſh! huſh! I'll hear no more.
Well, well, I'll ſay no more.
Coy prudence now no more reproving,
May joy our every hour beguile;
While on each heart Love ſmiles approving,
It beats reſponſive to his ſmile.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: Colonel Bentley, give me leave to congratulate you and our friends here on this agreeable diſcovery.

div.stage: Enter MUSHROOM, followed by TWIST and COROMANDEL.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: An agreeable diſcovery, indeed; but this ſeems to be a day of diſcoveries, and I believe, my dear, we are not yet got to the end of them.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: But I thought I heard ſomebody name Colonel Baton—is he arrived?

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Arrived! ha! ha! ha! Why the Colonel has been in company with you for this half hour paſt.—You have ſeen him—ſpoke to him—drank with him—Why here he ſtands—This is Colonel Baton. [pointing to Twiſt.]

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Is it? then he is a moſt extraordinary man, and I ſhould like to follow his example, for he is grown twenty years younger, at leaſt, ſince I ſaw him laſt.—Harkee, you dog—who are you?

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: Ah! mon ami—joy—joy—je vous felicite—I give you joy—here I am.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Pardon me, my dear friend, you have forgot yourſelf. There you are; [pointing to Twiſt] I find you have been here this half hour paſt—that I have talked with you, drank with you—and that there you ſtand at this moment.—Does not he, Muſhroom?

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: [to Twiſt.] Ah! ah! vilain! poltroon—I'ave got you. So you be Colonel Baton?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: No, Sir,—not the original Colonel Baton;—I am only a tranſlation from the French.

div.stage: [Mrs. Muſhroom takes Colonel Baton aſide, and confers with him in dumb ſhew.]

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: And a very free tranſlation too, for there appears to be great liberties taken with the original.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p:
[aſide to Baton] My dear Colonel, you muſt prevent an eclairciſſement—You
are bound as a man of gallantry to conceal that weakneſs which you have occaſioned.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: [to Twiſt.] Well, Sir; now for the whole truth.

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.—I am ſure I have found lying a very hazardous trade.—I'll tell the company the whole ſtory, from the beginning to the end.

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: No, Sair, it ſhall not be—Taizez vous.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Don't tell me of your taizez vous—I have got a letter in my pocket, from my wife to you; and, Sir, I ſhall inſiſt upon an explanation.

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: Here be my explanation, Monſieur. [putting his hand to his ſword.] You ſhall 'ave it venever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: [taking Eliza's hand] Here, Colonel; let me preſent you with another French tranſlation, a great favourite of mine.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: It is done by a woman, Madam, and of courſe, you know, claims an exemption from ſevere criticiſm.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: A woman!—How is all this, Stanmore?

sp.speaker: STAN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that lovely woman whom I thought irrecoverably loſt.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: A brave girl, i'faith. "I muſt ſalute her" [kiſſes her] Welcome, moſt ſincerely, my little heroine.

sp.speaker: CORO.
sp.p: Then you are not afraid of venturing on a military wife, eh, Stanmore?

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: Why ſhould he fear? Military diſcipline would teach me the moſt difficult duty of a wife—to obey.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Ah! Stanmore, you are a happy dog.—Zounds, I ſhall grow good-humoured in ſpite of myſelf.—I'll own neither man nor woman as my friend, who does not wear a ſmiling countenance.

sp.speaker: "WARNF.
sp.p: Then, Sir, your bounty has ſecured me a claim to your friendſhip."

sp.speaker: ORMEL.
sp.p: I own, my happineſs has received no trifling addition, in ſeeing my little friend here finiſh her campaign ſo ſucceſsfully.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p: And now farewell to the big war—my occupation's done. For though matrimony is ſometimes a ſervice of danger, I inliſt in hopes of remaining on the peace eſtabliſhment. What is your opinion of the matrimonial corps, Colonel Baton?

sp.speaker: BAT.
sp.p: Very reſpectable corps, Madame; I ſhould like to ſerve von campaigne, or ſo, in it—but den de diable be, dat von cannot give up de ſervice ven tired of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MUSH.
sp.p: And therefore the Colonel continues in the corps of Rangers.—"For my part, I do not regret the temporary cloud, which, for the firſt time in my life, has darkened my reputation, ſince it has tended to produce ſo fortunate an event. [to Ormellina.]"

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: "Some ladies are ſo generous, as not to value reputation, when it can be ſacrificed for a friend."—Hey-day, Muſhroom, you don't ſeem too happy, however.

sp.speaker: MUSH.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir,—I have been happy for theſe ſixteen years paſt; ever ſince I married Mrs. Muſhroom.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p:
And what ſays my old acquaintance,
whom I never ſaw before? He is a merry looking dog—what ſhall I do to make him happy?

sp.speaker: TWIST.
sp.p: Why, Colonel, my wiſhes are moderate, conſidering what old friends we have been (as Mrs. Muſhroom knows)—I ſhould be glad to be appointed your taylor in ordinary.

sp.speaker: BENT.
sp.p: Thank ye, thank ye, for aſking no more; for, in my preſent good humour, I could refuſe nothing.

lg.l: Griefs that are paſt, each joy enhancing,

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: See now deſcending from her throne,
Pleaſure, with fairy ſtep advancing,

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Points to the future, as her own.
No heſitation;
'Tis Mirth's invitation.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: At the glad call who would not advance?
Come away;
Who'll delay,

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: When Mirth and Pleaſure lead off the dance?
My joy, ſurpriſe, how can I tell?
I thought my dancing days were o'er.
And yet, you've practiſed pretty well:
She led you many a dance before.
As beau, or belle, with equal eaſe,
In this gay ſet, ſhe'll play her part:
We'll change our partners, if you pleaſe,
Ay, faith, cries he, with all my heart.
No heſitation;
'Tis Mirth's invitation.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: At the glad call who will not advance?
Come away;
Who'll delay,

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: When Mirth and Pleaſure lead off the dance?
My poor heart ſo dance with joy,
To ſee good friends here happy, bleſt.
Will you, Ma'am, find my heels employ,
And honour me?— [whiſpers to her] you gueſs the reſt.
Take hands, you ſlut, you ſha'n't refuſe
A warm, ſound heart, without a flaw:
Ah! could I but my partner chooſe! [looking at Baton.]
But he's too high for me.
Ah! ha!
No heſitation;
'Tis Mirth's invitation.
